title: This Week in Tech Earnings
text: Brent Thill, Jefferies analyst, discusses the weeks' tech earnings with Emily Chang on "Bloomberg Technology."

title: Tech Continues to Dominate
text: The market’s rebound has been following the surge from a select group of elite tech stocks. Why tech’s dominance won’t be ending anytime soon.

title: Facebook: Vexed By Discounts, So Now You Should Pounce
text: Facebook: Vexed By Discounts, So Now You Should Pounce

title: Facebook: Q1 Earnings Are In And FB Is Still A Buy After A Beat
text: Facebook: Q1 Earnings Are In And FB Is Still A Buy After A Beat

title: Big Tech’s Worries Should Worry You
text: When the most successful companies are anxious, you know we’re in scary times.

title: Tech Giant Posts Amazing Earnings Growth
text: Tech companies offering cloud and online experiences are finding people are using their services more than ever.

title: Facebook, Google and Snap have found their knight in shining armor as ad spending craters
text: As pandemic-related impacts started to cut advertiser budgets with big tech companies in the first quarter, one area of spend spend appeared to stay strong: Direct response.

title: Facebook Steps Into Game-Streaming: Here's What You Need to Know
text: Facebook had reported that it had five million installations of the application during its 18-month test run in limited market. Will it be able to rise above its rivals?

title: Big tech and ad firms were relatively unscathed by declining ad revenue in Q1, but Q2 outlook is darker
text: But though there appeared to be some green shoots from the tech giants in the realm of advertising, companies warned impacts will be felt in the second quarter and, in some areas, beyond.

title: The Most Important Takeaway That Drove Both Facebook and Alphabet Stocks Higher After Earnings
text: Executives from both companies echoed an important trend of interest to investors.

title: Absurdist Facebook Groups Are Thriving In The Pandemic
text: Facebook users are flocking to groups pretending to be anteaters, frogs and bees. Absurd, yes?
